results.title: Piaf
results.creator_credit: CBS, Fox Video, Franco London Film (Paris), Bill Siegler and Gary Halvorson
results.brief_description: This feature length filmed Broadway production (made for television) of Pam Gem’s play “Piaf” captures the very essence of the extraordinary and much-loved French singer, Edith Piaf. Jane Lapotaire won a Tony Award for Best Dramatic Actress in her role as Piaf and her portrayal of Piaf’s chaotic and emotion-charged life is inspirational. Lapotaire is ably supported by Zoe Wanamaker as Toine, David Leary as the Emcee/Manager, Judith Ivey as Madeleine and Peter Friedman as “Papa” Leplee. Cast also includes Nicholas Woodeson, Stephen Davies, Lewis Arlt and Robert Christian. Produced on Broadway by Elizabeth I. McCann, Nelle Nugent, the Schubert Organization, Ray Larsen in association with Warner Theatre Productions and directed for the stage by Howard Davies.

results.title: Piaf
results.creator_credit: Films Feuer and Martin, Martin Productions, Cy Feuer and Guy Casaril
results.brief_description: Biographical film adapted from the book “Piaf” by Simone Berteaut about Edith Piaf, the world renowned French torch singer also known as the “sparrow”. Piaf is still much loved and admired today with her unique voice and style being reinterpreted on stage and film across the world. This portrayal includes several of her original recordings including La Vie En Rose. Stars Brigitte Ariel as Piaf with Pascale Christophe, Pierre Vernier, Jacques Duby, Anouk Ferjac, Guy Trejan.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Films Feuer and Martin, Martin Productions, Cy Feuer and Guy Casaril

results.title: Pi [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Harvest Film Works, Truth and Soul Pictures, Plantain Films, Eric Watson and Darren Aronofsky
results.brief_description: Max Cohen (Sean Gullette) is a brilliant Jewish mathematician who has spent ten years of his life attempting to uncover the numerical pattern underlying the ordered chaos of the stock market. Max, who faces near-madness because of recurring debilitating seizures, finds himself mysteriously pursued by a Wall Street financier, and by a Hassidic Jewish group who believe that his mathematical work will assist them bring about the Messianic Age as ordained by the mysteries of the Cabalah. As he comes close to understanding chaos, Max finds his life and the very nature of his existence threatened by both the profanity of the capitalists and the sacred intentions of the Jewish Cabalistic cult. “Pi” owes a great debt the fevered imaginative writing of the Czech-Jewish writer, Franz Kafka. Just as in Kafka the madness of the individual cannot be separated from the madness of the world around him, so in “Pi”, Max’s fear of insanity is made more unbearable by the urban bleakness of New York City. The filmmakers also owe a debt to the existential visual and aural pioneering work of David Lynch: the stark black and white cinematography and the acidic techno score by Clint Mansell wonderfully accentuate the hallucinogenic intensity of the film. Philosophical, technically brilliant and economical in both execution and length, “Pi” is movie that explores one of the pivotal questions of contemporary human existence: are sacred and scientific aspirations completely antithetical? For all the dark intensity of the themes, “Pi” emerges as a strangely hopeful film.

results.title: Pi - the movie. Blind rage
results.creator_credit: Harvest Film Works, Truth and Soul Pictures, Plantain Films, Eric Watson and Darren Aronofsky
results.brief_description: Max Cohen (Sean Gullette) is a brilliant Jewish mathematician who has spent ten years of his life attempting to uncover the numerical pattern underlying the ordered chaos of the stock market. Max, who faces near-madness because of recurring debilitating seizures, finds himself mysteriously pursued by a Wall Street financier, and by a Hassidic Jewish group who believe that his mathematical work will assist them bring about the Messianic Age as ordained by the mysteries of the Cabalah. As he comes close to understanding chaos, Max finds his life and the very nature of his existence threatened by both the profanity of the capitalists and the sacred intentions of the Jewish Cabalistic cult. “Pi” owes a great debt the fevered imaginative writing of the Czech-Jewish writer, Franz Kafka. Just as in Kafka the madness of the individual cannot be separated from the madness of the world around him, so in “Pi”, Max’s fear of insanity is made more unbearable by the urban bleakness of New York City. The filmmakers also owe a debt to the existential visual and aural pioneering work of David Lynch: the stark black and white cinematography and the acidic techno score by Clint Mansell wonderfully accentuate the hallucinogenic intensity of the film. Philosophical, technically brilliant and economical in both execution and length, “Pi” is movie that explores one of the pivotal questions of contemporary human existence: are sacred and scientific aspirations completely antithetical? For all the dark intensity of the themes, “Pi” emerges as a strangely hopeful film. The short Australian horror film, “Blind Rage” screens before “Pi”. The short is directed Clayton Jacobson and Cameron Mellor and produced by Rohan Timlock.

results.title: Physics: an interactive approach
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Gilles Boivin and Jacques Parent
results.brief_description: This film demonstrates how the study of physics improves when students have the opportunity to work out the problems actively. Shown is a classroom-turned-laboratory, where films or film loops permit experiments to be staged on screen under control of the students. By starting or stopping films at will, any particular image or development can be measured on the screen and plotted on the students’ work sheets. Simple equipment for physics experiments is also shown.

results.title: Physics on television
results.creator_credit: Centre for Educational Television Overseas and Gordon Severn
results.brief_description: Some practical problems in producing an educational television program on physics. Shows good and bad displays, difficulties in showing laboratory equipment, use of filmed inserts, split screen and superimposition.

results.title: Physics in the world around us
results.creator_credit: Healthsharing Women. Publishing and Production Group and Lily Steiner
results.brief_description: Designed to encourage high school students to continue with physics studies. Looks at five different areas of physiscs, explains the basic principles and their relevance to daily life, future technology and job prospects.

results.title: Physics demonstration: Tyndall's apparatus
results.creator_credit: McGraw-Hill Films and MGM International Films
results.brief_description: This is a demonstration of the heat capacity of different substances. Balls of various metals, all of the same weight, are heated in boiling water, removed simultaneously and placed on a sheet of wax. The rate at which they melt through the wax is observed and the question is posed as to why the melting rates are different.

results.title: Physics and chemistry of water
results.creator_credit: Unilever Films, World Wide Pictures, Peter Bradford and Sarah Erulkar
results.brief_description: Explains how the molecular structure of water determines its unique properties, discussing the solid, liquid and gaseous phases, surface tension, solvent action and the thermal properties which provide a stable environment for life.

results.title: Physicists for industry
results.creator_credit: Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology, Trafford Price and John Garrity
results.brief_description: Promotes the various course of options in Applied Physics for prospective students. It emphasizes the practical project work involved and the fields of industry open to graduates. Such as the interior design for the acoustics at the Melbourne Concert Hall etc.
